intro: Iodes trichocarpa, commonly known as the western poison-oak, is a shrub native to the western United States. It belongs to the Anacardiaceae family and is characterized by its trifoliate leaves and clusters of small, yellowish-green flowers. The plant produces berries that are toxic to humans and animals, containing urushiol, which can cause skin irritation. It thrives in a variety of habitats, including woodlands and disturbed soils, and is often found in regions with Mediterranean climates. Due to its toxic properties, it is important to identify and avoid contact with this plant.
